content.webTitle: Centre Alliance may support Coalition on child sex offenders bill that divides Labor

fields.headline: Centre Alliance may support Coalition on child sex offenders bill that divides Labor
fields.bodyText: Centre Alliance is considering lending support to the Coalition’s bid to increase penalties for child sex offences, a bill that divides Labor because it contains mandatory minimum sentences. Labor, still in the grips of postmortems after its scathing internal election review, supports the intent to increase penalties but faces a difficult choice because the attorney general, Christian Porter, has signalled the government is unwilling to drop mandatory sentences. As senators return to Canberra for a Senate-only sitting week, the Law Council has accused the Coalition of attempting to wedge Labor with the legislation, while Labor will attempt to move on from the review by labelling itself the party of growth and targeting the government for its refusal to stimulate the economy. Senators Rex Patrick and Stirling Griff told Guardian Australia that Centre Alliance had not finalised its position on the sexual crimes against children bill. Griff said that although there was “strong public support” for mandatory minimums, the legal fraternity opposed them. The party would consider whether increasing maximums was sufficient to ensure “significant penalties” for serious offences without mandatory minimums, he said. Patrick said Centre Alliance was concerned the sexual crimes against children bill would result in an 18-year-old who sends naked images to a 15-year-old receiving a minimum five-year sentence. The party is considering asking the government to create separate categories of offences so only the most serious receive mandatory minimum sentences. “Our position is: anyone who interferes with a child ought to get a custodial sentence,” he said. Labor’s shadow attorney general, Mark Dreyfus, told Guardian Australia Labor “strongly supports the intent of sentencing reforms” to reflect the seriousness of child sex offences. “But we are concerned that mandatory sentencing undermines the effectiveness of this bill,” he said. In a dissenting Senate committee report, Labor has called for mandatory minimums to be removed but caucus has yet to decide if it will block the bill if the demand is not met. “Every non-government witness who gave evidence at the public hearing of the committee supported the suggestion that the bill proceed without mandatory minimum sentences,” Dreyfus said. “In the interests of protecting our children, Labor strongly urges the government to heed this advice.” The Law Council president, Arthur Moses, said “mandatory sentencing sounds like getting tough on crime but it is pure rhetoric” and there was “no evidence” it reduced crime. “Parliamentarians should not be wedged into supporting measures that won’t work but will throw up a range of unintended consequences.” Sign up to receive the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning Porter said that mandatory sentencing was the “one guaranteed mechanism … that can ensure child sex offenders stay behind bars for longer”. “It is time that Labor made the hard choices to support mandatory sentencing of child sex offenders.” Despite its hesitation over the child sexual offences bill, Labor has been consistent in its opposition to the union penalties bill, which leader Anthony Albanese on Sunday labelled an “attack on the organisations that go into workplaces that deal with issues like wage theft”. Albanese told ABC’s Insiders that he had always supported “aspiration” and Labor’s task is to “ensure that we’re the party of wealth creation – not just concerned about distribution”. The language echoes the findings of the internal review that Labor did not craft and convey a persuasive jobs and economic growth story that augmented its mission to reduce inequality. On Monday the shadow treasurer, Jim Chalmers, will accuse the Morrison government of a “cancer of complacency” as it appears “frozen in the headlights” in the face of slowing growth. Chalmers will tell the John Curtin Research Centre that the choice between growth that is strong and growth that is fair is “false”. “The world’s best economists have come around to Labor’s long held view that growth is stronger when it is fair – when more people have a stake in it,” he said. “We champion growth and redistribution, not growth or redistribution.” In a draft of the speech, Chalmers warns that growth is “too weak, too uncertain, and too narrow” and is not “trickling down to the people nor out to the suburbs”. “The Australian economy needs responsible, proportionate and measured stimulus to get it going again.” Chalmers will accuse the Coalition of prioritising “political posturing over policy action”, “stubborn, smug inaction”, in reference to its refusal to use fiscal policy to stimulate the economy in addition to interest rate cuts, and persistent “anti-union rhetoric”. The Coalition is also banking on Centre Alliance to pass its union penalty bill, after the minor party offered support in return for a range of amendments that lift the threshold for deregistration of unions and disqualification of their officials. Patrick told Guardian Australia the minor party is “close to finalising an agreement” whereby the bill’s penalties and the proposed public interest test for union mergers will all be subject to a demerit point system. An individual would be liable for deregistration if they accrue 180 court-ordered penalty units for legal breaches, while unions would be liable if they reach 900 points. Porter said drafting of amendments is advanced and he looks forward to the bill being debated in the Senate as soon as is reasonably possible.
